abstract.text: Creates a texture that shares its storage with the buffer.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The descriptor that contains the properties of the texture.
The offset, in bytes, from the base address for the first row of texture data.
The stride, in bytes, from one row of texture data to the next.
A new texture that shares the buffer’s underlying storage.
This method creates a new
instance that uses the same data as the buffer’s. Modifying the buffer also modifies the new texture because they share the same underlying memory.
Metal may not be able to optimize a texture that shares memory with a buffer.

The texture’s resource data is coherent between multiple render passes. However, data accesses within a single render pass may not be coherent due to caching at runtime. For example, a texture from this method may not be able to immediately access new values from a render or kernel function that modifies this buffer.
If this buffer’s
is
, and a render or kernel function modifies it, the CPU can access the new values through a texture after calling the
method. CPU accesses are only coherent between command buffer boundaries. GPU barriers guard a GPU’s accesses to buffers and textures so that each access finishes running before the next one begins.
You can create multiple, nonoverlapping textures that use the same buffer; however, the GPU serializes accesses to those textures.
You can avoid the GPU’s texture access serialization by creating multiple buffers and then creating a texture from each buffer with this method.
To create a linear texture, you need to:
Align the
and
parameters to the value that the
method returns.
Set the
parameter to a value greater than or equal to the number of bytes in one row of pixels — the product of the row’s width, in pixels, and the size of one pixel, in bytes.
Additionally, creating a linear texture from this method adds the following restrictions for the
parameter’s properties:

abstract.text: Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
Encodes a command that synchronizes the CPU’s copy of a managed resource, such as a buffer or texture, so that it matches the GPU’s copy.
A resource that stores data in a format defined by your app.
Creates a texture that shares its storage with the buffer.
The main Metal interface to a GPU that apps use to draw graphics and run computations in parallel.
Returns the minimum alignment the GPU device requires to create a linear texture from a buffer.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the GPU device supports the feature set of a specific GPU family.
Represents the Apple family 1 GPU features that correspond to the Apple A7 GPUs.
Represents the Apple family 2 GPU features that correspond to the Apple A8 GPUs.
The data formats that describe the organization and characteristics of individual pixels in a texture.
A pixel format where the red and green components are subsampled horizontally.
A pixel format where the red and green components are subsampled horizontally.
The location and access permissions of the resource.
Modes that determine the texture coordinate at each pixel when a fetch falls outside the bounds of a texture.
Texture coordinates are clamped between
and
, inclusive.
The CPU and GPU may maintain separate copies of the resource, and any changes must be explicitly synchronized.
A resource that holds formatted image data.
An object that you use to configure new Metal texture objects.
The number of array elements for this texture.
The depth of the texture image for the base level mipmap, in pixels.
The number of mipmap levels for this texture.
The size and bit layout of all pixels in the texture.
The number of samples in each fragment.
The location and access permissions of the texture.
The dimension and arrangement of texture image data.
Options that determine how you can use the texture.
A two-dimensional texture image.
A texture buffer.
An enumeration for the various options that determine how you can use a texture.
An option for rendering to the texture in a render pass.
Prototype and test your Metal apps in Simulator.

abstract.text: Optimize a texture’s data to improve GPU or CPU access.
Learn the common attributes of all Metal memory resources, including buffers and textures, and how to manage the underlying memory.
Describes an unsigned integer.
A signed integer value type.
